review.title: Belief Merging by Source Reliability Assessment
review.abstract: Merging beliefs requires the plausibility of the sources of the information to be merged. They are typically assumed equally reliable in lack of hints indicating otherwise; yet, a recent line of research spun from the idea of deriving this information from the revision process itself. In particular, the history of previous revisions and previous merging examples provide information for performing subsequent mergings.

sections.heading: 7 Multiple classes
sections.text: The division of the sources into two classes is based on a very clear distinction: A source is either reliable (it always provides the right information) or unreliable (it can provide incorrect information); the tripartition is also sharply defined: a source always, sometimes or never provides the right information; partitions in four or more classes cannot be based on a similarly uncontroversial division; but a source that provides three correct formulas out of four is more reliable than a source that provides one out of five. Each partition has a set of maximums; and b. Each maxim induces a partition. Abstracted from the specific realization, a partition is a way to represent the relative reliability of the sources, and maxim is a way to condense formulations.

sections.heading: 7.1 Percentage bounds
sections.text: The most obvious extension of the method is the distribution of the sources to the percentage of correct formulas that they provide, which allows as many classes as desired. For example, the first class contains the sources that provide only correct formulas, the second, which provide between 90% and 100% of correct formulas, etc. The problem with any method of this kind is that the limits are arbitrary: why is the reader not asked to accept a division based on some fixed limits with some intuitive appeal: reliability is tied to 90%, unreliability to 50%. These numbers consider a source as reliable if it provides 90% or more of the correct formulas, unreliable if it delivers less than 50% of them.

sections.text: Another way to implement the principle of reliability of the sources from a possible result of the merger is the use of orders for both. However, the meaning of the third class changes depending on the direction considered: Partition → Maximum formulas are included in the third class if they match the formulas of the first two; maxset → Partition, a source goes to the third class if all of its formulas are incompatible with the maxim. This underscores the ambiguity of the definition of a source that is "absolutely unreliable." It can be a source that is less reliable than all the others, but in principle it can provide correct information, but it can also be a source that always provides wrong information.The third class can therefore be divided into two categories. sections.heading: 8.4 Flexible bounds
sections.text: Splitting up the sources to 100% and 0% of the correct formulas, as with duplicates and triplicates, is based on a qualitative notion of reliability and unreliability, any other limit (such as 80% or 50%) is difficult to motivate compared to others (such as 90% and 51%).One possible solution is to assume that such a partition (S1 | S2S3 | S4) only means that there is a reason to believe that S1 is more reliable than S2 and S3, which are both more reliable than S4, without requiring two fixed boundaries between them. As an example, this division is acceptable if the four sources provide 80%, 72%, 69% and 30% correct formulas; the limit can be set to 75% and 50% to support this division, but also to 79% and 60% or 79% and 40%. This mechanism overrides the decision on an exact pair of correct formulas to define a source reliably or reliably partially.

metadata.abstractText: Merging beliefs requires the plausibility of the sources of the information to be merged. They are typically assumed equally reliable in lack of hints indicating otherwise [12]; yet, a recent line of research spun from the idea of deriving this information from the revision process itself. In particular, the history of previous revisions [3, 15] and previous merging examples [16] provide information for performing subsequent mergings. Yet, no examples or previous revisions may be available. In spite of the apparent lack of information, something can still be inferred by a try-and-check approach: a relative reliability ordering is assumed, the merging process is performed based on it, and the result is compared with the original information. The outcome of this check may be incoherent with the initial assumption, like when a completely reliable source is rejected some of the information it provided. In such cases, the reliability ordering assumed in the first place can be excluded from consideration. The first theorem of this article proves that such a scenario is indeed possible. Other results are obtained under various definition of reliability and merging.
